content:
Right now the styling is a bit inconsistent throughout the app. While the buttons, unread counter, panels etc have a bit of curve, the message row is a bit blocky and feels out of the place. I attached a rough mockup example of what it should look like. There are a bit of other things that does the same thing. I'm open for inputs from the community, also was thinking to include this as a part of my proposal?
Screenshot
image.png

I agree...
It will be great if we follow some sort of modern design standards

Siddharth said:

I agree...
It will be great if we follow some sort of modern design standards

+1
I personally think most of the UI can be changed to make it more modern.

Siddharth said:

I agree...
It will be great if we follow some sort of modern design standards

Rounded corners aren't a modern invention. :slight_smile: It's just a question of taste here. If you go to Twitter, their message view has sharp corners as well.

There's a consistency argument that if you are avoiding rounding in the message view, then you should also avoid rounded corners in buttons. I'm not sure I completely buy that argument, as the rounded corners of button (which is usually fairly subtle) makes it clear that things are buttons.

Note the sharp corners around the messages here, while the button has rounded corners. Incidentally, Thoughts of Dog :dog: is a good twitter follow:

image.png

Yes, I agree sharp corners on button is not goona look good
I am not just focusing on the message view, but the overall design of zulip...like how we play with shadows, font-size and all things
if we see, we rarely use shadows

I think avoiding shadows is still somewhat an aesthetic decision, which I'd argue is actually a somewhat modern trend (although there will always be opinions on both sides). If you go overboard with shadows and make every button look beveled, it can have kind of a 90s feel.
true :sweat_smile:

@Steve Howell Yeah curves are no modern design concept but the round corner are easier on the eyes. Most of the mobile apps like facebook has updated to use round corner in most of the part of their apps. The drop shadow is sign of elevation, one of the key features of material design. So round corners + elevation + muted colors can be good design choice. Also one of the changes would be distinction between sidebars and main message container. Slack and Discord both has stream/channels column a different color while Zulip uses a same color for all of the columns.
Another quick mockup of the topbar - Group-2.png
Those look like buttons to me.
Is this the top navbar, btw? @Tejas Tank
To be clear, they do function like buttons (although I never press them).
The top navbar is under re-design already, so it's kind of an unfair thing to pick on--we know that needs improvement.
@Vinit Singh Yeah, it's a very rough design though.
@Yash RE has an on-going project to redo the top navbar entirely and, apart from some minor issues, I think it's almost finished.
If you're interested in this, it'd be a great idea to connect with him and help with testing, etc.
We had it deployed here on czo for a while, and I think the design at the time was really great.
Yeah, I did have a look at his topic. Although I haven't looked at it in working. I'll try pull his branch if he has his branch updated.

If not the complete UI, I do have a list of minor improvements that can be done.

  • Highlight a particular message when hovered, that would make it easy to track a message for functions. Like when I hove on the second message it can add a bg color.
    image.png

  • Add a different tone to side bars for better distinction. (Like slack and discord)

  • Reduce contrast between different elements. Eg- Like when we are not using night mode, the settings dropdown's border creates a stark contrast between it and the body, while contrast is necessary, it's too much here. We can compare it to Google's dropdown menu's in their GSuite.
    image.png
    image.png

These all seem like great things to think about. When I have more time I can dig up some past design ideas folks have played with, but I think it's probably best to let you thing independently for a while before doing that :slight_smile:
For the top navbar, I wouldn't spend much thought because we have a major redesign in-progress (unfortunately it's proven difficult to implement what we want for various migration-related reasons).

Oh okay no problem, I thought improving UI should be one of the major factor for new onboarding users. Should I list down every UI fixed along with mockup here? just include a point of improving UI in the proposal and iterate later on?
Like I have a pretty neat solution for this - https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues/9382
But writing down every UI fixes in proposal can take bit of time along with mockup.

For onboarding new users, most of the design issues are more usability-related than cosmetic.

Of course, I will grant you that cosmetic changes can help with onboarding new users to the extent that they will probably have a more positive view of the app and might be more patient to get past usability concerns.

Tejas Tank said:

But writing down every UI fixes in proposal can take bit of time along with mockup.

I think any re-design effort at this point is going to be inherently time-consuming, so it's probably just worth accepting that. And then you want to think about how best to advocate for your vision. The best way to do that is to communicate your vision with writeups and mockups, I think.

I get that, the above linked issue should come under usability. The solution is to move every action items at top (like bootstrap collapse) and the later options like members/stream about etc at bottom in similar way.

Ok, I think this topic has diverged into two different conversations:

  • Things like message row styling are mostly cosmetic.
  • Things like #9382 are more about basic usability.

For #9382 I think we should just open up a new topic. I don't think there's any controversy about #9382. Nobody's pushed back on it, and Tim labeled it high priority. It's just the case that nobody has claimed that particular issue. I would be thrilled to see it fixed.
I'll start a new topic here called "add user to stream".

pull #11894 and check it out

Please do, feedback is appreciated, esp. from ui/frontend focused people. #design > top navbar or #code review > #11894 (updated top navbar) are fine places to give feedback. If lots of people are interested in constructive criticism, we could even test deploy on czo again (this years gsoc students haven't seem much of the design and might have additional insight).

Another thing that frontend/ui people might want to checkout is #design > ideas for a new theme. Hope no one minds me bringing that topic up again :neutral: .
I kinda want to start a thread talking about our new design vs slack and discord's design / approach, but don't have enough bandwidth for that rn.
@Yash RE I'm open to talk about UI/UX and happy to help out in that particular field.
